lexicon_requests.reason: Liturgical technical term - root meanings (נצח) and cultic function across psalm superscriptions
Theological puzzle - does 'forever' mean eternity or hyperbolic duration? Semantic range crucial
Key ambiguity in v.3 - does it mean 'counsels/plans' (self-reliance) or 'cares/sorrows'? Context unclear
Grief vocabulary - distinguish from other sorrow terms, trace covenant curse contexts
Imperative demanding divine attention - semantic force vs. other 'look' verbs (ראה, שקף, פקד)
Central theological verb - does it mean physical eye healing, enlightenment, or face-showing? Range critical
Unusual 'sleep of death' construction - why this verb vs. simple מות? Sheol theology implications
Enemy victory language - root יכל semantic range (prevail, overcome, be able) in combat contexts
Enemy terminology - distinguish from אֹיְבִי used earlier, nuance of oppression vs. hostility
Tottering/instability metaphor - track usage in covenant stability/judgment contexts
Covenant love term - how it functions when divine face is hidden, steadfastness despite absence
Critical verb in prophetic perfect construction - does it mean 'deal bountifully', 'recompense', or 'benefit'?

concordance_requests.purpose: Track fourfold anaphora pattern - where else does this complaint formula appear and in what density?
Divine forgetting + forever formula - covenant crisis language across Scripture
Hidden face formula - trace covenant curse contexts esp. Deuteronomy 31:17-18
Grief in heart formula - inward suffering language patterns
Enemy exaltation over psalmist - spatial dominance metaphor usage
Eye illumination petition - chiastic reversal of hidden face, track all contexts
Sleep of death metaphor - track Sheol theology and death-sleep connections
Enemy triumph speech formula - where else do enemies speak of prevailing?
Trust in steadfast love formula - lament-to-trust transition patterns
Heart rejoicing in salvation - body imagery in anticipated deliverance contexts
Vow to sing to YHWH - praise before deliverance patterns
Divine benefaction formula in prophetic perfect - treating future as accomplished

figurative_requests.reason: Hidden face as covenant curse reversal of Aaronic blessing - vivid and theologically central | Vehicle: hidden face | Related terms: hide face, hides face, hiding face, conceal face, conceals face, concealing face

Spatial metaphor of enemy 'lifted up' (ירום) over psalmist - dominance imagery | Vehicle: lifted up | Related terms: lift up, lifts up, lifting up, exalt, exalts, exalted, exalting, raise, raises, raised, raising

Eye illumination/restoration of luster - light as life metaphor central to chiasm | Vehicle: illuminate | Related terms: illuminates, illuminating, light, lights, lighting, brighten, brightens, brightening, shine, shines, shining
Death as sleep metaphor - eyes closed/darkness connection to Sheol theology | Vehicle: sleep of death | Related terms: sleep, sleeps, sleeping, slumber, slumbers, slumbering

Tottering/instability (אמוט) as vulnerability - physical instability metaphor for crisis | Vehicle: totter | Related terms: totters, tottering, stumble, stumbles, stumbling, slip, slips, slipping, shake, shakes, shaking

commentary_requests.reason: Superscription formula - how do commentators interpret למנצח and Davidic attribution's liturgical function?
Fourfold anaphora opening with divine forgetting and hidden face - traditional understanding of covenant crisis language
Key ambiguity of עצות (counsels vs. cares) and chronic grief specification - classical resolution of semantic puzzle
Triple imperative structure and eye illumination petition - how commentators explain chiastic reversal of hidden face
Enemy speech and theological stakes of their triumph - traditional interpretation of covenant reputation concern
Unexplained reversal and prophetic perfect (גמל עלי) - how commentators account for trust without narrative deliverance

macro_questions: What is the theological significance of God 'forgetting' (שָׁכַח) in covenant contexts? How does this relate to God 'remembering' Noah (Gen 8:1), Rachel (Gen 30:22), and the covenant (Exod 2:24)?
How does 'hiding the face' (הסתיר פנים) function in Deuteronomistic theology (Deut 31:17-18; 32:20) versus Psalms? Is this metaphor exclusively negative, or can it be disciplinary?
What does עֵצוֹת (cares/counsels) signify in v. 3? Does this suggest mental deliberation, anxiety, or futile self-reliance versus trust in God's counsel (Ps 1:1; 73:24)?
How does the 'sleep of death' (אִישַׁן הַמָּוֶת) relate to Sheol theology and the psalmists' understanding of death as silence (Ps 6:6; 30:10; 88:11-13)?
What is the function of the enemy motif in individual laments? Are these concrete historical enemies, spiritual forces, death itself, or symbolic representatives of anti-God forces?
How does חֶסֶד (steadfast love/faithfulness) function as the theological hinge enabling the shift from complaint to trust? What is its covenantal freight?
What is the temporal logic of בָטַחְתִּי (perfect: 'I have trusted')? Does this indicate habitual past action, or is it a performative present masked as perfect?
Is גָמַל עָלָי (he has been good/dealt bountifully) a true prophetic perfect, or does it recall past deliverances as warrant for present confidence? What other psalms use this verb?
How does Psalm 13's structure compare to other brief laments (Ps 3-7)? Is the speed of transition from lament to trust proportional to psalm length, or is this uniquely abrupt?
What is the significance of singing (שׁיר) as the final verb? How does song function differently from prayer/petition in Psalms? Does singing require deliverance first, or can it precede it?
How do the LXX additions in v. 6 ('I will sing to the name of the Lord Most High') expand the psalm's theology? What does this reveal about early interpretive traditions?
micro_questions: What is the semantic range and theological freight of עֵצוֹת in v.3 - does it mean anxious deliberations, futile self-counseling, or simply 'cares'? How does this word choice relate to divine counsel theology elsewhere in Psalms?
Why does the psalm use the unusual phrase 'sleep of death' (אִישַׁן הַמָּוֶת) rather than simply 'die' - what does the sleep metaphor contribute to understanding Sheol/death theology in Psalms?

How does the fourfold עַד־אָנָה repetition function symbolically - is there significance to four (divine name tetragammaton, cardinal directions, completeness) or is this simply maximum tolerable repetition?

What accounts for the abrupt shift to trust in v.6 without any narrative explanation (no theophany, oracle, or tangible deliverance) - is this a performative speech act where declaring trust constitutes trust?

Is the final verb גָמַל עָלָי (v.6) a true prophetic perfect (future treated as accomplished) or does it recall past deliverances as warrant for present confidence? What other psalms use this verb in similar contexts?
Why does the petition for eye-illumination (הָאִירָה עֵינַי) specifically reverse God's hidden face rather than simply asking 'show your face' - what does the eye/light focus contribute?
Who are the enemies in vv.3,5 - personal opponents, national foes, death personified, or symbolic anti-God forces? How does their vagueness function rhetorically?
What is the relationship between חֶסֶד (steadfast love, v.6) and God's hidden פָּנִים (face, v.2) - can covenant love persist when covenant face is absent?

How does the LXX expansion in v.6 (adding 'I will sing psalms to the name of the Lord Most High') interpret the original Hebrew theology - what does this reveal about early Jewish understanding of praise-before-deliverance?
Why specify 'grief in my heart all day' (יוֹמָם) in v.3 - does night bring relief, or is this synecdoche for totality? What does temporal specification contribute to the complaint?
What is the function of direct enemy speech ('I have overcome him') in v.5 - is this hypothetical or remembered taunt, and how does it intensify the theological stakes?
